course_title: Literacy and Numeracy Across the Curriculum

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate comprehensive and well-founded knowledge and understanding of the nature of literacy and numeracy in the 21st century, related issues and opportunities for effective pedagogical practice.
Demonstrate sophisticated research informed knowledge, understanding and analysis of explicit literacy and numeracy teaching and learning strategies and their application in their teaching areas.
Apply contemporary research, select and evaluate literacy and numeracy resources, including ICTs, to effectively engage students in literacy and numeracy learning in their teaching areas.

Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of strategies for involving parents/carers in their child’s literacy and numeracy learning and identify professional strategies to effectively engage with parents/carers sensitively and confidentially.
Demonstrate clear, fluent and coherent communication, which is appropriately referenced and consistent with personal, professional academic conventions.

Demonstrate and apply ethical practices appropriate for the teaching profession and an understanding of the place of legislative, school and employing authority requirements in the teaching and learning process.
Demonstrate an understanding of schools as workplaces and be familiar with the statutory, ethical and other requirements that govern the work of teachers in schools.

assessments.due_date:
Module 1. 20/03/2026 2:00 pm

Module 2. 24/04/2026 2:00 pm

Module 3. 22/05/2026 2:00 pm

Each module and timed assessment will be open to pre-service teachers three weeks before the due date and time.
assessments.mode: Activity/ Performance, Product/ Artefact/ Multimedia, Written
assessments.task_description:
To develop and assess your knowledge and understanding of core content for this course, you are required to complete three online modules:

  • Module 1 — With the brain in mind: explicit reading instruction using phonemic awareness and phonics
  • Module 2 — Effective numeracy teaching and learning: Mathematics strands and proficiencies
  • Module 3 — “It takes a village”: Building active and professional relationships with parents and carers for effective literacy and numeracy learning.


These online modules will:

  • engage you in key subject matter and explicit teaching strategies, specific to their focus
  • require you to apply your learning in cross-curricular as well as teaching area contexts
  • provide opportunities to check your understanding as you progress through each module
  • require you to complete a timed assessment at the end of each module.


To complete each timed assessment, you will need to apply your knowledge and understanding of the specific module focus, by responding to multiple choice and/or short response items on related stimulus materials (e.g. a scenario or problem, an excerpt from a student response, a teaching artefact, other).

Your participation in lectures and tutorials, and engagement with course readings and other Blackboard resources, should also be used to consolidate your knowledge and understanding of core content.

More information on how to approach and complete these modules will be made available via the course Blackboard.

Focusing Australian Professional Standards for Teachers (APSTs) for this assessment — Graduate career stage: 2.1, 2.5, 3.7 and 7.3.

Core Content Learning Outcomes assessed:

  • 2.4: Appropriate subject matter expertise in the effective teaching of literacy, including the explicit teaching of phonics in early reading and the explicit teaching of reading and writing in subjects other than English.
  • 2.5: Appropriate subject matter expertise in the effective teaching of numeracy including the explicit teaching of mathematics and building of fluency, understanding, problem solving and reasoning.
assessments.submission_guidelines: If you do not pass a timed assessment, you may reattempt until the due date and time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: Each module will close on the due date. You will not be able to complete or reattempt after this time, unless you have an approved extension via myUQ.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: AT2 Research essay — literacy teaching and learning
assessments.task_description:
Write an essay in which you analyse two practical teaching strategies for explicit literacy instruction in one of your teaching areas, and address how these strategies could be used in a culturally responsive classroom to support students with English as an additional language/dialect (EAL/D).

Your essay will need to:

  • demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the literacy demands of your teaching area, drawing on relevant curriculum documents (e.g. from the ACARA, the QCAA)
  • focus on one practical teaching strategy for explicit reading instruction and one for explicit writing instruction, ensuring each:

--- specifically targets the literacy demands of your nominated teaching area

--- is informed by current theories associated with literacy teaching and learning

--- is aligned with course content (e.g. explicit teaching and learning for vocabulary acquisition, reading comprehension, fluency, genre-based approach, other)

  • discuss and justify your selected strategies using current theories as well as relevant curriculum documents
  • discuss how these strategies could be used in a culturally responsive classroom, to support literacy learning of students with EAL/D.

In preparing and submitting your response, ensure you:

  • use a minimum of five course readings
  • use other recent peer-reviewed literature (published within the past five years, unless the document is a seminal work in the field of study)
  • write using academic prose, without images or bullet-points. Given the focus and purpose of this essay, you may use sub-headings and/or first person
  • use APA7 referencing conventions to acknowledge all sources, including a generative AI/machine translation technology statement. See the UQ Library guide and course Blackboard for more information.

Focusing Australian Professional Standards for Teachers (APSTs) for this assessment — Graduate career stage: 2.1 and 2.5.

Core Content Learning Outcome/s and Focus Area/s assessed:

  • 2.4: Appropriate subject matter expertise in the effective teaching of literacy, including the explicit teaching of phonics in early reading and the explicit teaching of reading and writing in subjects other than English.
  • Focus Area: Cultural responsiveness, including EAL/D students.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission to TurnItIn via the course Blackboard by the due date and time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: AT3 Design and presentation of a numeracy lesson plan
assessments.weighting: <dd>50% — Completed template + 5-7 min presentation; up to 2000 words + reference list/appendices </dd>
assessments.due_date:
Part 1: Lesson design, spoken rationale and peer feedback scheduled 5/05/2026 - 14/05/2026

Part 2: Final lesson design and account due 2pm 29/05/2026
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Presentation
assessments.task_description:
This task requires you to engage in an iterative process of lesson design for numeracy teaching and learning in one of your teaching areas.

For Parts 1 and 2 of this task, you will need to use:

  • the templates and submission advice provided in Blackboard to prepare and submit your response
  • use APA7 referencing conventions to acknowledge all sources, including a generative AI/machine translation technology statement. See the UQ Library guide and course Blackboard for more information.

Engagement with the course reading list, Blackboard resources, and activities in lectures and tutorials, should be used to consolidate your understanding of task requirements. 

Part 1: Lesson design and spoken rationale 

Design a 50-minute lesson for a middle school class that targets the numeracy demands of one of your teaching areas. Then present your design to an audience of fellow pre-service teachers for peer feedback.

You will need to design your lesson using:

  • the Australian Curriculum v9.0 (Years 7 to 10)
  • the 21st Century Numeracy Model (see Goos, et. al., 2019)*
  • your understanding of effective numeracy teaching, learning and task design from course readings and activities, including explicit teaching of mathematics and building of fluency, understanding, problem solving and reasoning
  • a range of teaching strategies and resources, including ICTs, to support learning and engage students.

To present your design, you will need to:

  • prepare a spoken rationale of 5-7 minutes to deliver in your scheduled tutorial

--- detailing your lesson and how it targets the numeracy demands of your chosen teaching area

--- justifying your design choices, supported by curriculum documents and course reading on numeracy

--- including visuals where appropriate, e.g., in sharing and making clear your lesson design

  • be prepared to respond to questions from your peers and tutor at the end of your presentation.

You are also required to provide feedback on your peers’ lesson designs in your scheduled tutorials.

Presentations will be recorded for moderation purposes.  

Part 2: Final lesson design and account

Using peer feedback and design requirements, critically evaluate and finalise your numeracy lesson. Then write an account of your final design, explicit enough for understanding and implementation by a teacher in your teaching area.

You will need to:

  • return to and evaluate your lesson design from Part 1, drawing on peer feedback and your understanding of the review process and design requirements. 
  • refine your lesson design as needed, ensuring you document changes made, what informed these changes and how they have improved the design of your numeracy lesson.
  • develop and submit a written analysis of your final numeracy lesson, including justification of refinements you made in its design.

Focusing Australian Professional Standards for Teachers (APSTs) for this assessment — Graduate career stage: 2.1, 2.5 and 3.4.

Core Content Learning Outcome/s assessed: 2.5: Appropriate subject matter expertise in the effective teaching of numeracy including the explicit teaching of mathematics and building of fluency, understanding, problem solving and reasoning.

*Goos, M., Geiger, V., Dole, S., Forgasz, H., & Bennison, A. (2019). Numeracy across the curriculum: research-based strategies for enhancing teaching and learning. Allen & Unwin.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Part 1: Completed template uploaded to TurnItIn. In-class presentation and feedback.

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.

learning_activities.topic:
An introduction to literacy and numeracy: general capabilities for the 21st century

  • Defining literacy and numeracy: an intersection of theory, research, curriculum and policy 
  • History and evolution of literacy and numeracy education, including the digital age
  • Reading, writing and numeracy across the age range, socioeconomic and cultural contexts 
  • The role of critical literacy and numeracy in personal enablement and social empowerment  
  • The value of discipline-specific expertise and cross-curricular communities of practice

learning_activities.topic:
An introduction to literacy & numeracy: challenges and possibilities for teaching and learning

  • Personal perceptions and experiences of literacy and numeracy as learners and pre-service teachers
  • Defining and identifying literacy and numeracy in and out of the classroom
  • The value of discipline-specific expertise and cross-curricular communities of practice 
  • The role of critical literacy and numeracy in personal enablement and social empowerment of secondary students in the 21st century

learning_activities.topic:
Literacy and numeracy in and across the curriculum

  • Literacy and numeracy in the Australian Curriculum v9.0 as general capabilities and their relationship with the English and Mathematics strands and proficiencies
  • The Australian Curriculum v9.0 literacy and numeracy learning progressions 
  • Literacy and numeracy as complementary skills in the QCAA senior syllabuses

learning_activities.topic:
Cross-curricular and subject-specific demands and opportunities

Identifying literacy and numeracy demands and opportunities in teaching areas: 

  • Using the Australian Curriculum v9.0 Year level content descriptions and elaborations, the literacy and numeracy general capabilities and their learning progressions
  • Literacy and numeracy as complementary skills in the QCAA senior syllabuses

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 3 To Week 5(09 Mar - 29 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Cross-curricular and disciplinary literacy teaching and learning

Lectures 3 to 5:

  • Listening, speaking, reading, writing and designing across the curriculum, in contemporary (including digital) contexts 
  • Traditional, Socio constructivist, functional and genre-based approaches to literacy teaching and learning
  • With the brain in mind — the relationship between reading and writing, and the importance of systematic and explicit teaching
  • Phonemic awareness, phonics, fluency, vocabulary acquisition, comprehension and oral language
  • Writing structures and conventions, grammar, punctuation and spelling 
  • Meeting the demands of discipline-specific and increasingly complex texts in secondary schooling
  • Literacy (and an introduction to numeracy) for learners with English as an additional language/dialect, including literacy development to access the curriculum and respecting and caring for Funds of Knowledge and Funds of Identity in Culturally Responsive literacy teaching
learning_activities.topic_title: Cross-curricular and disciplinary literacy teaching and learning

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 3 To Week 5(09 Mar - 29 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Strategies for literacy teaching and learning across the curriculum

Tutorials 3 to 5:

  • Creating healthy listening, speaking, reading, writing and designing classroom cultures
  • Identifying and meeting the reading and writing demands and opportunities of the curriculum and subject disciplines
  • Research-based activities and strategies for reading and writing across the teaching and learning cycle
  • Using ICTs to enhance students' literacy learning and development
  • The ACARA EAL/D learning progression and the importance of cognitive academic language proficiency (CALP) 
  • Valuing and mobilising cultural difference, repertoires and intelligences for literacy learning

Due 2pm Friday, Week 4: AT1 Module 1 — Effective reading instruction using phonemic awareness and phonics

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 6 To Week 8(30 Mar - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Cross-curricular and disciplinary numeracy teaching and learning

Lectures 6 to 8:

  • Recognising and overcoming learner and teacher “maths anxiety” 
  • Understanding the Mathematics strands and proficiencies, and their relationship to numeracy in the Australian Curriculum v9.0 
  • Effective instruction of mathematical concepts and skills within and beyond the mathematics curriculum  
  • Numeracy as context-based, sociocultural practice and the need for a cross-disciplinary 21st century approach
  • Understanding and modelling “mathematical noticing” and “mathematical thinking” 
  • The significance of ICTs in 21st century numeracy and numeracy teaching and learning
  • The relationship between numeracy and literacy across the curriculum
  • Numeracy for learners with English as an additional language/dialect

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 6 To Week 8(30 Mar - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Strategies for numeracy teaching and learning across the curriculum

Tutorials 6 to 8:

  • Recognising and overcoming learner and teacher “maths anxiety”, for healthy classroom numeracy cultures
  • Identifying and meeting the numeracy demands and opportunities of the curriculum and subject disciplines
  • Applying the 21st Century Numeracy Model, other research-based strategies, "mathematical noticing" and "mathematical thinking" in classrooms
  • Using the 21st Century Numeracy Model to design rich and authentic numeracy tasks in teaching areas, including the use of ICTs 
  • Explicit instruction and gradual release of scaffolding to develop students as independent problem-solvers 
  • Valuing and mobilising cultural difference, repertoires and intelligences for numeracy learning

Please note, the mid-semester break (below) falls between Teaching Weeks 6 and 7.

Due 2pm Friday, Week 7: AT2 Research essay 

Due 2pm Friday, Week 8: AT1 Module 2 — Explicit numeracy teaching and learning: Mathematics strands and proficiencies

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 9 To Week 10(27 Apr - 10 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Literacy and numeracy for diverse learners

Lectures 9 and 10:

  • The value of designing, shaping and critically evaluating literacy and numeracy teaching and learning as an iterative process  
  • Unpacking the data and unboxing the literacy and numeracy learner: gender, socioeconomic status, linguistic and cultural differences 
  • Deficit and strength-based approaches to literacy and numeracy teaching and learning, including differentiating literacy and numeracy teaching and learning and Universal Design for Learning 
  • Co-constructing First Nations perspectives and knowledges in literacy and numeracy teaching and learning

Tutorial 9 — Case study workshop:

  • Deficit and strengths-based approaches to literacy and numeracy learners and learning in diverse classrooms

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 11 To Week 13(11 May - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Assessing literacy and numeracy / "It takes a village"

Lectures 11 to 13:

  • Diagnostic, formative and summative assessment of literacy and numeracy 
  • The role and use of national and international testing, e.g., NAPLAN, PISA 
  • Meeting numeracy and literacy requirements for the Queensland Certificate of Education
  • Strategies for active and professional relationships with parents and carers 
  • Whole-school approaches to literacy and numeracy teaching, learning and assessment

AT3 Spoken presentations / Using literacy and numeracy data and assessment

Tutorial 11: AT3 Part 1 — Spoken rationales and peer feedback

Tutorials 12 and 13 — Case study workshops:

Working with

  • the Australian Curriculum v9.0 literacy and numeracy progressions, student responses, and student and school NAPLAN data
  • student, teacher, school and parent/carer perceptions of literacy, numeracy, testing and reporting

Using literacy and numeracy assessment and data in

  • whole-school approaches to improving literacy and numeracy outcomes
  • differentiating literacy and numeracy teaching and learning to meet the needs and strengths of students
  • active and professional relationships with parents/carers
